newsitem.title: SWEDEN: New threats as police dismiss Stockholm bomb claim.
newsitem.headline: New threats as police dismiss Stockholm bomb claim.

text.p: Police dismissed on Wednesday a claim by a group calling itself "We Who Built Sweden" that it started a string of fires in Stockholm and set off a bomb to sabotage the city's bid to stage the 2004 Olympics.
But Swedish media received two more communications, apparently from the same group, threatening violence against athletes if Stockholm was chosen to host the 2004 Games.

Sweden's national news agency TT, which received the first claim by letter on Monday, was sent a fax on Wednesday evening and a newspaper in western Sweden, the Gothenburg Post, received a similar letter by mail. Police were investigating both items.

Stockholm police commissioner Gunno Gunnmo said analysis of the first letter showed "no evidence to support the suggestion that the person or persons behind the letter should be involved in the incidents."
"The person or persons have simply taken advantage of incidents that have already occurred," Gunnmo said.
In the letter, We Who Built Sweden said it was responsible for eight fires at sports venues in the Swedish capital and a bomb explosion last Friday at a stadium built for the 1912 Stockholm Olympics.
The group threatened to target athletes and the public if Stockholm was awarded the 2004 Olympics.
Police released no details of their analysis of the letter but police spokesman Claes Cassel said "the picture of the letter as a whole" led them to conclude it was a hoax.
TT said it received the second threat via its fax machine after the police statement dismissing the group's claim.
"If Stockholm gets the Olympic Games in 2004 poison arrows will be shot with blowpipes and air pistols at both athletes and certain people of high ranking," the typed fax said.
TT said the fax had no telephone or contact number, but was signed with the initials V.S.B.S. used by We Who Built Sweden.
Cassel told TT that the Gothenburg Post received a letter signed "V.S.B.S. - commando Gothenburg" and threatening further violence if Stockholm won the right to stage the 2004 Olympics.
Four other cities -- Athens, Buenos Aires, Cape Town and Rome -- are bidding for the 2004 Olympics. The decision will be made on September 5.
